@Hasu @_prestwich @bcmakes 17/ And last but not least, as usual thanks to @JacobPPhillips for doing research work on this!

@Hasu @_prestwich @bcmakes 16/ Networks currently trust in economics; in the future, networks will trust in cryptography. \n \n Cryptoeconomics might be just be a bandage, a short term fix to help bootstrap the crypto ecosystem until cryptography can provide real security.
@Hasu @_prestwich @bcmakes 15/ With ZKPs, centralization in staking networks no longer becomes a huge issue, as the value a validator can extract from an attack is decreased significantly.

@Hasu @_prestwich @bcmakes 14/ There may only be one way to truly secure these networks long-term ‚Äî Zero-knowledge Proofs. \n \n Rather than relying on economic mechanisms to keep validators honest, ZKPs make it impossible for validators to perform malicious behaviors like producing an invalid block.

@Hasu @_prestwich @bcmakes 13/ It's looking increasingly like centralization in staking may be inevitable. \n \n If this is the case, bribery for chain reorganization (i.e. Binance hack) & censorship may always be within the realm of possibility.

@Hasu @_prestwich @bcmakes 12/ These mechanisms may help discourage centralization but ultimately won't stop it. Validators will find ways around these rules. (e.g. running multiple nodes, ignoring out-of-protocol 'rules')

@Hasu @_prestwich @bcmakes 11/ C) Incentivize delegating to smaller validators ‚Äî ex. Polkadot's Nominated PoS (NPoS) that distributes rewards to validators evenly regardless of stake. This helps small validators bootstrap delegation.

@Hasu @_prestwich @bcmakes 9/ In the context of PoS, this means slashing must be used to impose a cost on misbehavior. Without slashing, validators have little "commitment" to the network. \n \n Networks w lower slashing may tend to be less secure, and it seems unlikely that a slashless PoS could be secure.
7/ What does this mean for PoS security? \n \n Well, we can't rely on honest & uncoordinated majority assumptions to drive security ‚Äî collusion must be assumed to be possible and probable.

6/ Even in an efficient validator market, stake concentrates to a few large validators who utilize reputation and scale to drive smaller validators out of the market. \n \n Binance using unsustainably low fees to undercut the market is the latest example of this.

5/ Validators have 3 ways to differentiate: 
 
 1. Pre-existing reputation 
 
 2. Fees ‚Äî offer higher return to delegators 
 
 3. Differentiated services (i.e. offer better staking experience or additional crypto services)

4/ So why is stake concentrating? A big part of this is the inefficiency in delegation markets. 
 
 On paper, validators look the same, so delegators crowd into a few validators with a large amount of stake, decent track record, and low fees. 
 
 Power laws take over.
3/ When stake becomes concentrated, collusion becomes a real risk. "Trustless" networks are replaced with networks that only trust a few. True censorship-resistance arguably goes away.

2/ Running a validator well is hard & requires technical expertise ‚Äî it's definitely not for everyone, so we let users delegate their stake to other people running validators. \n \n But this is causing stake to gravitate toward a small number of publicly-known validators.

1/ Coinbase adds automatic staking for XTZ, and less than a month later, Binance introduces 0% staking fees on Tezos. 
 
 Stake wars are just getting started, and things are already starting to feel a liiittle uncomfortable. 
 
 A thread on centralization in Proof of Stake (PoS):

The main complaint the banks are making is that they worry the new secured overnight financing rate (SOFR) could notch outsize drops at times of economic stress. Banks might then have to lend at low rates at times when their own borrowing costs are rising.

After all the criticism that LIBOR (London Interbank Offered Rate, i.e. the rate at which banks lend to each other, and reference rate for most loans) has received over the past several years, it's interesting to see regional banks struggling to find an acceptable alternative.

@JacobPPhillips 20/ Crypto won't achieve this vision on its own, but it can be a major asset to developers along the way. Thanks again to @JacobPPhillips for being a thought partner on these topics ‚Äì‚Äì go give him a follow! \n \n /END

@JacobPPhillips 18/ And third, tokenized assets can be a tool to improve gameplay. \n \n Tokenized assets enable individual asset ownership (no trust assumptions or centralized honeypots), increased transparency (verifiable scarcity), and better cost/UX of trading, among other things.

@JacobPPhillips 15/ And 1 broad observation: Trust in gaming is not broken. \n \n GCs don‚Äôt flood the market with assets or delete user accounts. Popular 3rd party sites aren‚Äôt stealing assets or scamming people, and gamers aren‚Äôt particularly cynical of the GCs who control the gaming experience.

@JacobPPhillips 14/ Third, right now, trading probably makes games less fun. \n \n The ability to trade in-game assets for $ creates a huge incentive for hackers to exploit the centralized entities controlling asset issuance and trading. Widespread cheating undermines the integrity of the game.

@JacobPPhillips 13/ Second, there is clear demand for markets around in-game assets. \n \n Many gamers have been persistent in their pursuit of this practice. They routinely work around (or outright defy) the rules to allow for suitable asset trading. It's clear that the demand is here to stay.

@JacobPPhillips 11/ Many gamers use 3rd party trading sites to reduce fees & enable cashing out to USD. When gamers use 3rd party sites, GCs are unable to profit. \n \n These sites are more risky ‚Äî users often have to share account info, opening door to scams (e.g. site steals all your assets).

@JacobPPhillips 10/ Some games permit asset trading. GCs capture value through trading fees on official exchanges. \n \n Steam is the most popular exchange. Gamers who trade here are charged ~15% commission per trade. Gamers can load USD to buy assets on Steam but can‚Äôt cash out to USD post trade.

@JacobPPhillips 9/ Most games prohibit markets for in-game assets, fearing that resale markets will reduce in-game spending. \n \n But even when restricted, gamers always find ways to trade for real money. P2P 'gifting' and asset swaps are common loopholes.

@JacobPPhillips 8/ Side note: the loot box model has been deemed gambling in some places. This model becomes more gambling-like when paired with an out-of-game market to trade assets for $$$. \n \n Some assets trade for many $100's, even $1000's, of dollars.

@JacobPPhillips 6/ In the world of in-game assets, GCs are the central bank. They can mint, destroy, restrict, or alter assets at anytime. Gamers don't own assets, and assets can only exchanged if allowed by the GCs.

@JacobPPhillips 5/ When you look at the numbers, in-game assets are a BIG deal. Take Fortnite, for example: 
 
 - $2.4bn in revenue, almost all from in-game assets 
 - 70% of users buy in-game assets 
 - Average spending per user = $85

@JacobPPhillips 4/ The economics here seem to make sense: People are more likely to make multiple small purchases than one large purchase. \n \n Plus, the game is free ‚Äî why not spend a few bucks to make it more fun?

@JacobPPhillips 3/ In the FtP model, game creators (GCs) make money by selling/issuing in-game assets. \n \n These assets don't improve performance. Skins, outfits, accessories, and other assets are purely cosmetic. Gamers use these as a form of expression ‚Äî to look cool and signal expertise.

@JacobPPhillips 1/ The gaming industry has undergone a rapid shift. The early 2000s were dominated by play-then-play gaming ‚Äî i.e. pay $ to buy game, then play as much of you'd like. Call of Duty, World of Warcraft, Fifa, etc. all used this model.

@zcash @avichal 14/ Huge thanks to Autonomous Partners analyst @JacobPPhillips for helping research + put together our POV. He's new on twitter ‚Äì‚Äì give him a follow! /END
@zcash @avichal 13/ Our full comments can be found here. We welcome community feedback! https://t.co/PwCvm0xBSJ

@zcash @avichal 12/ Rationale for staggered elections: This helps reduce governance volatility. In corporate governance, staggering is commonly used to avoid hostile takeovers. Also, one election at a time is more digestible for the community‚Äîleading to higher participation.

@zcash @avichal 11/ Rationale for removing miner seat: PoW miners are not necessarily aligned with the broader community. Ex. If Zcash finds PoS to be more secure/scalable, this will hurt miners, so the miner rep would vote no. However, miners can still hold ZEC and vote!

@zcash @avichal 10/ Rationale for 1 seat to ECC, 1 to ZF: Zcash is ECC's brainchild; they've amassed an R&D team that is 2nd to none. ZF has been huge in pushing adoption. We should welcome ECC & ZF leadership. If they fail expectations, we have an simple & formal way to replace them.

@zcash @avichal 9/ Rationale for 5-person council: this strikes a good balance between centralization and decentralization. We get quick, flexible funding with broad representation of interests. A council of people is better than entities because they're easier to replace.

@zcash @avichal 8/ Rationale for 20% of block reward for dev fund: this should be enough to fund development. Underfunding poses an existential threat to Zcash. Overfunding is slightly inefficient. Better to be safe than sorry.

@zcash @avichal 7/ ASP rec's accepting Avichal‚Äôs proposal with two revisions: \n 1. In the initial allocation, 1 seat is reserved for an ECC rep., 1 seat is for a ZF rep, and 3 seats are for ZEC holders to vote on. \n 2. Staggered elections. Every 6 mo's, 1 seat should be put up for a vote.

@zcash @avichal 6/ Avichal‚Äôs key points are: 
 1. 20% of BR to Dev Fund. 
 2. 5-person council is created and has full authority over funds. 
 3. 1 seat on the council is for a miner rep. 1 seat is for a ZEC holder rep., and the remaining 3 seats can be anyone. 
 4. Elections every 2 years.
@zcash 5/ ASP's positioning most closely aligns with @avichal's proposal: https://t.co/qMXQNzbu4f.

@zcash 4/ Here's what's still being debated: 
 1. How large should the Dev Fund be, and how should it be funded? 
 2. How will the Dev Fund be managed? 
 3. How will the Zcash community ensure transparency and accountability of the managers of the fund?

@zcash 3/ Here's what the community agrees on: 
 1. The FR should be allowed to expire. 
 2. There should be a fund for ongoing development (Dev Fund). 
 3. We need great transparency and accountability. 
 4. More input from Zcash community is needed on how funds are distributed.
@zcash 2/ 20% of each block reward (BR) is paid to the FR. \n But this is set to expire at the first BR halving in 2020, at which point all the BR will go to miners

@zcash 1/ Quick background for those who aren't familiar with the FR discussion: The Zcash FR is a fund used to reward Zcash founders, early employees, and investors. FR funds are also used to fund ongoing development through the Electric Coin Company (ECC) & Zcash Foundation (ZF)
0/ We just released our opinion on the Zcash Founders' Reward (FR) debate. Here's a thread on our post in the @Zcash forum.

9. Parking your capital in a high interest-generating account (i.e. DeFi) is ultimately taking a different path toward solving for the same issue. So to pit ethereum and bitcoin against one another is to majorly miss the big picture.
8. Ray Dalio did a terrific job of laying out the case for us but missed by a fraction of an inch when he landed on gold as the solution: more here https://t.co/90bwvGbC0b
7. In this kind of a macro environment, holding bitcoin is a hedge against the failings of fiat currencies.
6. There is no sign of a reversal, either: the ECB cut its deposit rate by 10 basis points last week to a record low of -0.5% and markets are signaling they don't expect a reversion for a decade.

5. DeFi is offering this environment which has become exceedingly rare at the macro level. In traditional capital markets - interest rates are often no longer just low but now even negative, a logical impossibility which is becoming increasingly common in much of the world.
4. The minimum environment people are looking for is the ability to break even (interest rate ‚â• inflation rate) but ideally, one where interest rate > inflation rate.
3. Interest (and relatedly, leverage) has been emerging as the initial killer app of DeFi. They are two sides of the same coin. It comes down to *not having your money vanish* over a period of time.
2. Bitcoin is called "sound money" - capped, limited supply, known quantity, resistant to inflation. It is particularly attractive as a counter to hyper-inflationary monetary regimes.

1. It's an easily overlooked issue so it doesn't surprise me that it's under-discussed, but the fact is that bitcoin and defi are solving for some of the main problems in the traditional monetary system. THREAD:

11/ On the whole, I remain extremely excited and optimistic about what other chains will bring to the table. But being glib about the risks involved strikes me as a recipe for disaster. As usual, never a dull moment in crypto.... üôÉ

10/ As if that weren't enough, as new chains become more complex, the surface area for vulnerabilities becomes dramatically larger. It's easier to have bugs, and easier for malicious actors to exploit those issues - and as discussed, there's more incentive to do so.

9/ And part of it is just about the money - if you've raised 100M +, people are going to expect that your chain has its shit together at time of launch. In this kind of environment, the iterative process is much tougher.
8/ Developer expectations are (rightly) much higher today than they were when bitcoin or even ethereum launched. Part of that is projects today should be able to benefit from and build on prior art.
7/ The environment today looks very different, and is much more antagonistic. There are 10s if not 100s of millions of dollars to be made by attacking top chains, and that # is rising.
6/ If syphoning off bitcoin only netted you a few hundred bucks, it would hardly be worth the trouble. This let bitcoin develop into a robust state by the time it started getting more attention.

5/ This was actually a terrific stroke of luck - since approximately 4 people cared, few eyes were upon it, and almost nobody was trying to attack the chain. In bitcoin's early years, there was basically no financial incentive to break it.

4/ While we'd all like to think that bitcoin came into the world fully formed, perfect, and entirely bugless, that's not the case. What happened is that bitcoin launched into relative oblivion (read: general sentiment was IDGAF).
3/ There are many classes of users here. Mainly for L1 chains I'm talking about developers, as they will ultimately be the ones to decide, via voting with their feet, which chain(s) win.

2/ The history of software development shows that building in a vacuum and expecting to come out with the perfect solution basically never works. Development is an iterative process which often involves many false starts and should have user feedback at its core.

1/ As we get closer to the launch of a number of Layer 1 chains that raised big money in 2017 and early 2018, I've been thinking a lot about what those launches are going to look like and whether they will pan out as early investors might have hoped.

9/ So in sum, I believe claims that "alts are dead" and bitcoin alone will make it are nonsensical. I am most definitely long BTC. But call me after you've tried deploying an app on bitcoin versus ethereum -- alternative chains might not seem so useless after all! üôÉ

8 / I actually don't believe many other cryptoassets are even directly competitive with BTC -- if it captures the "digital gold" category, there is no reason other cryptonetworks cannot own other categories (compute, storage, etc etc).

7/ But given the numerous high caliber of teams who are building crypto networks, I think it is incredibly unlikely that over a period of several years the entire rest of the market amounts to nothing. Not to mention, other chains will serve different functions!
6/ Anyone who knows me (or has followed me on twitter for more than 5 minutes) is aware of how bullish I am on BTC. If I could only hold a single asset, BTC would be it.
5/ In reality, ETH was a better performing investment for many (even when considering the major correction of 2018!) than BTC was. So BTC remains king, but discounting everything else is silly.

4/ Those who have been in this space for many years should recall that this is by no means the first time the pendulum has swung back and forth -- in 2017 bitcoin was old news and it was all the shiny new layer1s that were going to take over the world.

3/ Why? First off, there is a strong recency bias in the crypto community (and in the investing world at large, tbh). Just because something has been the case lately does not mean that will persist in perpetuity.
2/ BTC has clearly outperformed most other cryptoassets by a wide margin YTD. Expecting that this will always be the case (or that holding only BTC is the right move) strikes me as foolish.

6)Lastly, put yourself in the way of interesting people and things. Work hard, but leave a little bit of space for randomness. Most of my most pivotal life and career moments came because I was out meeting people, not holed up in an office 100% of the time.
5) If you hate your job, leave. Life's too short, and I think people who aren't miserable are generally more productive and better contributors to the world. You deserve to be happy!

4) Don't delay spending time with people you love until you're "successful enough". People get sick, die. Babies grow up. You won't get that time back and that is a regret you may hold on to forever.

3) If you're young, have no debts, and no dependents, make some asymmetric investments bets ‚Äì‚Äì even with small amounts of money. If you're right, it'll pay off in a major way, and if you're wrong, you'll be able to make up for it. Mine was bitcoin.

@CeloHQ 13/ \n You can developing on Alfajores, run a node, provide feedback, host a meetup...visit https://t.co/AfT92wdKok for more. And yes, my fund is an investor in Celo!
@CeloHQ 12/ I have been incredibly impressed by the speed and caliber of execution I have seen from the Celo team. It takes a village, though, so we'd love your participation.

@CeloHQ 11/ To make rapid development & iteration possible after launch, Celo uses an on-chain governance protocol for upgrading itself using a straightforward mechanism that rewards users for participation.

@CeloHQ 10/ For the technically minded: Celo removes the need to check every header before a received header can be trusted. Performance will also improved with BLS signature aggregation and succinct zero-knowledge proofs, via zk-SNARKs.

@CeloHQ 9/ Data connectivity is often poor, and expensive, so Celo provides fast, secure sync between mobile devices and the network. Even wallet users with high latency, low bandwidth, or high cost data tariffs can use it.
@CeloHQ 8/ This design allows for people to send payments to people that are not yet on the protocol (in a fully decentralized manner), which is awesome as it helps grow the community natively.

@CeloHQ 7/ The protocol verifies these phone numbers & users can earn coins by helping to power the texting infrastructure needed to perform these verifications (running an app on their phone that sends text messages on behalf of the protocol, etc).

@CeloHQ 6/ Concepts like wallet addresses are confusing and users prefer using phone numbers ‚Äî Celo maintains a decentralized on-chain PKI that maps hashes of phone numbers to public keys so that users can easily find each other via phone number.

@CeloHQ 5/ To keep it simple, txn fees must be payable in the asset being sent ‚Äî Celo supports paying for gas using these stable assets (in addition to the native asset), and support for new assets that follow the ERC-20 standard can be added easily via on-chain governance.

@CeloHQ 4/ Stability relative to local or strong reference fiat currency (e.g. USD) is critical, so Celo uses its own algo stability protocol that supports a family of stable digital assets (pegged to local and global currencies), all backed by the same crypto-asset reserve.
@CeloHQ 3/ This lead them to some very specific design decisions, including the following:

@CeloHQ 2/ \n \n Celo's mission is to make financial tools open to people all over the world, and the team has spent a huge amount of time doing user testing across the globe in cities, refugee camps, and rural areas to make sure they are building something people really need.

6/ On that note, Erasure is just the first of many dapps that can be built on Erasure ‚Äì‚Äìand while Numerai has its own hedge fund that will trade based on these signals, eventually this will become an open market for data and predictions.

5/ Hedge funds are constantly looking for an edge, and opening up an ongoing tournament that allows ANYONE to build models is a novel approach to sourcing predictions, and one that should lead to a much more open hedge fund industry.

4/ Erasure also ties in the concept of identity ‚Äì‚Äì you build reputation by revealing your past predictions, and the fact you have a unique identity is a key part of incentivizing good behavior, particularly so in an ongoing game, effectively with multiple rounds.
3/ The fact that these are provable (meaning you can demonstrate you made the prediction in advance) is new. This is fucking rad! There is currently no good way to do this.

2/ Quant is the first dapp built on Erasure (Numerai's protocol), which will launch later this year. The basic idea is simple: it's a stock picking tournament that allows you to make provable point-in-time stock predictions.

20/ Either way, prediction markets are an interesting way to tap the wisdom of the crowd. And the new decentralized versions are going to be MUCH tougher to shut down than their predecessors. End!
19/ One of the toughest issues facing PMs is their murky legal situation: some jurisdictions consider it gambling, while others view is as options trading.

18/ Augur still has a lot of challenges ahead ( low liquidity across most markets, hard to use UX, etc), so many folks are building on top of it. @veil built on top of Augur to offer a better experience -  but recently forked (more here): https://t.co/U00bLYe5Nu

17/ Augur's contracts are fully automated. Developers do not control how market outcomes resolve, approve or reject trades or other transactions, have the ability to spend funds that are held in escrow, and cannot undo trades or cancel orders.

16/ Prior to Augur, PMs have all been centralized, with trades being aggregated by a central entity that maintains a ledger, determines market outcomes, and distributes payouts to traders. A decentralized network removes many of the risks of selfinterest and corruption.

15/ REP plays a central role in Augur‚Äôs operations, but is not used to trade in its markets. After the event on which a market is based has occurred, the outcome is determined by Augur‚Äôs oracle and traders can close out their positions and collect their payouts.

14/ The outcomes of Augur‚Äôs PMs are chosen by users who hold Augur‚Äôs native Reputation token (REP), used for reporting and disputing the outcomes of\nevents. These users stake their REP on the actual observed outcome and receive settlement fees from the markets in return.

13/ Augur is a trustless, decentralized PM platform built on Ethereum. Its markets follow four stages of progression: creation, trading, reporting, and settlement. Anyone can create a market based on any realworld event and trading begins immediately after market creation.

12/.....Annnnnnnd enter decentralized prediction markets! There are a few main platforms: Augur, Gnosis, etc., but @AugurProject seems to be where most of the action is happening right now so I'll focus on that here.

11/ In '12, Intrade was sued by the CFTC and was forced to block all US users from the real-money markets. In '13, Intrade suspended all trading on the platform citing possible "financial irregularities". For a while after they said they might relaunch, but no dice.

10/Founded in '01, Intrade was another online PM. It provided both real-money and fake money trading and allowing users to trade contracts for elections, sports matches, etc. Intrade became the world's leading PM platform during the '08 and '12 US presidential elections.
9/ The HSX is still up and running today, but remains merely a simulation of a real-money stock exchange.

8/ In '09, Hollywood got together and successfully lobbied Congress\ninto inserting a provision in the financial-reform bill that outlawed movie-futures trading. Too much of a threat! The speculation itself on how a movie would fare could affect real behavior and be damaging.

7/ In '01, brokerage firm Cantor Fitzgerald acquired HSX with the aim of turning it into a real-money exchange. The entire Hollywood establishment (stars, studios, management, theater owners, and distributors alike) hated this idea.

6/ While PMs have gotten a lot of hype in crypto, they're not new. Hollywood Stock Exchange (HSX) was one of the first digital PMs. Founded in '96, it's an entertainment stock market game where movie buffs can predicting the earnings of new movies in their 1st month in theaters.
5/ There are 3 most common kinds of PMs: 1) Binary (yes or no) 2) Categorical (multiple discreet outcomes) and 3) Scalar (outcome resolves within a given range)
4/ Participants partake in PMs by purchasing and trading contracts, where the value of a contract will vary depending on the outcome of a future event.

3/ They rely on the collective wisdom and info of a group, and allow participants to place bets on the probability of specific outcomes, where the value of a bet directly reflects the probability of an outcome occurring.

2/ Prediction markets are exchange-traded markets with the purpose of trading on the outcomes of future events. Events can be anything where the results can be objectively verified, like sports games, political elections, horse races, price fluctuations of commodities, etc.
1/ Time for a thread on prediction markets! One of the most fascinating yet poorly understood areas of DeFi, IMHO. Let's explore...

17/ One drawback of the platform is that its automated market making mechanism makes it so that the larger a trade, the more price slippage occurs. The platform works well for smaller trades, but this makes it somewhat unusable for larger ones.

16/ Worth nothing also that Uniswap is very gas efficient. It uses almost 10x less gas than Bancor in ETH to ERC20 trades (440,000 vs 46,000 gas), and can perform ERC20 to ERC20 trades more efficiently than 0x (113,000 vs 88,000 gas).

15/  This goes into the liquidity reserves to ensure that the total reserve size in the exchange contract continually grows with each trade. The fees also serve as a payout to liquidity providers when they withdraw their holdings of the reserves.

14/ When this happens, the provider's ETH and tokens are withdrawn at the current exchange rate (reserve ratio), rather than the ratio of their original investment. Uniswap itself does not take any commissions, but each txn by users is charged a 0.3% liquidity provider fee.

13/Liquidity tokens are ERC20 tokens themselves and are specific to a single exchange pair (there is no uniform native token for the platform). Providers can burn their liquidity tokens at any time to withdraw their proportional shares of ETH and ERC20 tokens from the reserves.

12/ When deposits occur, liquidity tokens (LTs) are created for the provider, so they can earn passive income from lending their coins to the reserves. LTs track the proportion of total reserves that each liquidity provider has contributed.

11/ 1st liquidity provider to deposit into a contract sets its initial exchange rate by depositing an equivalent value of ETH and the respective token. If the ratio is off, arbitrage traders bring the prices to equilibrium (at the expense of the initial provider).
10/ But how does this actually work? Liquidity is added to exchange contracts via liquidity providers depositing equivalent values of ETH and ERC20 tokens into them.

9/ This pooled model smooths out the order book and allows for narrower spreads, requiring less active management on the part of market makers. Set it and forget it, FTW! (For more on the upsides of a pooled model, see @alexhevans's recent piece: \nhttps://t.co/28dnwTx2GI)

8/ For example, if an ERC20 token is being sold for ETH, the size of that token's\nreserve in its exchange contract increases and the ETH reserve decreases. The mechanism shifts the reserve ratio to increase the price of the ETH relative to the token for future txns.

7/ The constant product market maker formula calculates the exchange rate at which a trade will be executed based on the size of the transaction and the amount the incoming trade will shift this ratio.

6/ Unlike other DEXs where traders buy/sell based on prices + volumes in an order book, Uniswap's exchange contracts act as automated market makers, where prices are set automatically using the constant product market maker mechanism, which keeps reserves in relative equilibrium.

5/ Each of these contracts holds reserves of both ETH and the respective ERC20 token, creating an internal liquidity reserve. Trades are executed directly against these reserves. Exchange contracts are linked through the registry, allowing for direct token to token trades via ETH

4/ What's novel about it? Most exchanges maintain an order book and facilitate\nmatches between buyers and sellers, but Uniswap doesn't. The protocol is composed of an ETH-ERC20 exchange smart contract for each ERC20 token on the platform.

3/ Uniswap is open source, has no native token or platform fee and no incentives or special treatment awarded to early adopters or developers. Listing tokens is free and all smart contract functions are public.

2/ First off, what is it? It's a protocol for automated exchange of ERC20\ntokens on the Ethereum blockchain. It prioritizes decentralization and security and has eliminated rent extraction and censorship, enabling faster and more efficient exchange.

4(c)/ Last but not least, you benefit as a MM whether you are big or small. MMs don‚Äôt benefit from forming a coalition or multiple identities. Conversely, small MMs aren‚Äôt at a disadvantage, unlike on most exchanges which only extend discounts or subsidies to high-volume traders.

4(b)/ If you stake ZRX, your reward will increase as you supply more liquidity. If you supply liquidity, your reward will increase as you stake more ZRX. Wash trading and faking volume becomes very expensive.

4(a)/ They use a thing called a Cobb-Douglas production function to calculate liquidity rewards, which has a number of nifty attributes, including the following: If you provide zero liquidity, you earn zero reward. If you stake zero ZRX tokens, you earn zero reward.

6/ Yuuuuup I‚Äôm an investor in @marbleprotocol and yuuuuup I think this is awesome. The team would love your feedback so feel free to reach out w questions or comments!

5/ Polaris is also inexpensive to maintain (based on an average of ~200k gas per poke, 5 Gwei gas price, and historical ETH/DAI Uniswap volatility, the estimated yearly cost for a network of incentivized pokers to maintain the oracle would be ~20 ETH.)

4/ What‚Äôs the incentive system? In order to reward third party reporters to maintain accurate feeds, Polaris charges smart contracts a monthly subscription fee for the ability to read prices from the oracle. They‚Äôre rewarded w Oracle tokens that be redeemed for revenue.
3/ So, what‚Äôs different here? Polaris makes attacks more costly by taking the median of price checkpoints over time. Attacks are not impossible but become much more expensive.

2/ Why does this matter? Oracles are critical in crypto as an on-chain source of truth. The issue is that most current ones are either centralized, easy to manipulate, or lack incentives to keep feeds accurate over time.
1/ Super excited to see this launch! Awesome work by the ‚Å¶@marbleprotocol‚Å© team. ‚ÄúIntroducing Polaris‚Äù by @mykelp https://t.co/vPyIJpV7xm https://t.co/t9q6Dugr5V

4/ Occasionally you‚Äôll encounter an asshole who doesn‚Äôt behave this way, but on average people really are hoping you‚Äôll succeed(I assure you the jerks are just insecure). It‚Äôs a much more comfortable view of the world ‚Äî and when you‚Äôre at ease, you‚Äôll be more likely to deliver!

3/ The same is true if you‚Äôre a founder going into a fundraising conversation. Investor mtgs can be nerve wracking (especially pitching a whole partnership) but think about it ‚Äî they are all hoping you‚Äôll be the best company they‚Äôve ever seen! It‚Äôs literally why they‚Äôre there.

3/ When I was younger I used to get very nervous before speaking in public, but once I reframed it in this way, it became much more appealing thing to do. A whole room full of supporters listening! What an awesome thing to have.

2/ Public speaking is a great example. Most people fear it more than death (seriously, they‚Äôve done studies) but in reality, think about it: when someone goes to hear a talk, they don‚Äôt want it to suck! They are literally invested in your success.

7/ Can anyone point to any research on this? Very curious what studies have been done on this concept.

6/ It seems to me that learning by topic, (i.e. for several weeks JUST learn about cell biology, then move on to history of WW2)by combining different formats of learning -- videos, lectures, reading multiple books on the subject etc would be a MUCH more effective way to do it.

5/ But school, esp pre-college, does the opposite! Students are constantly being shuffled between different classes, which are generally no more than an hour. So you never go very deep on anything. Everything stays in the short/medium term category of surface-level understanding.

4/ If you go super deep on something for an extended period, it transfers from "think I remember now but could forget" to something that you really KNOW. The latter is much more valuable as it's basically permanently rather than temporarily held in memory.
3/ The key part of the process is that I am TOTALLY focused on learning one thing, and one thing only. I am increasingly convinced that context switching is the enemy of deep understanding.

2/ plus what others have written, watching videos, etc. Then I usually find founders or people who know way more about it than I do and ask them questions until i feel like I get it. Then I explain it to somebody else (either live or in a memo / LP letter) to confirm I get it.

2/ How I currently learn about a new topic (i.e. how predictions markets work, or how Uniswap works) is by doing a complete deep dive for a few days, or in some cases longer, until I feel like I really understand it. This meanings reading source material like whitepapers ..(cont)

10) That‚Äôs all! If anyone has other tips would love to hear about them üòä

9) Use tech: I use @goodreads to keep track of books, Leio to keep track of time spent reading, and Highlighter to save passages. I‚Äôm a super tracker of all the things, so these make it more fun and improve retention for me.

8)Library: the library is such an awesome and under appreciated resource. It eliminates cost from the equation and allows you to experiment more (if you don‚Äôt like the book, no pressure to finish cause you paid for it!)Just move on.
7) Set ambitious goals: # of books per year, # of minutes per day etc. Even if you don‚Äôt hit them you‚Äôll likely read much more than you would have otherwise.
6) Interest: i only read things that genuinely interest me. Fortunately for me that‚Äôs a wide array, but everyone can find something they love to read. If you haven‚Äôt found it, keep looking!

5) Block time: if you feel like you don‚Äôt have enough time, literally block it off on your calendar. Most of my best ideas have come from reading (often outside of my professional arena). Amazing how things transfer and you can recombine ideas in original ways.

4) Style: I own a kindle but don‚Äôt love it. Tried to make myself like it for years (and consequently read less) but eventually gave up. I find my retention is way worse on Kindle. Find what works for you!

3) Preparedness: I bought this handy little book light that I have in my bag all the time and use to read whenever it‚Äôs dark, especially in Ubers at night. It‚Äôs rechargeable and lasts forever. So nerdy but I love it! https://t.co/cEEnFduanJ

2) Variety: I keep lots of books on hand, and am generally reading 2-4 at a time, of different genres. Alternating allows me to pick whatever suits my mood at the moment (sometimes I‚Äôm too tired for non fiction but fiction is perfect, etc).

1) Availability: I always, always have a book on me. Down time becomes time to read rather than mindlessly browsing Instagram. Added plus: any delay is much less of a nuisance since I can make productive use of time.

6/ Like anyone else, I can make no guarantees about what will happen, especially short term. What I can say is that what is happening here is a paradigm shift ‚Äîand those never come painlessly. But if you are willing to stick around for it, you just might find it worth your while.

5/ Think about the reasons you got in the space to begin with. Is the only thing that has changed the price, or is it something more fundamental? Perhaps not worth changing your thesis or behavior if it‚Äôs the former.

4/ I encourage you not to flop around, (especially if you‚Äôre a fund manager as year end nears). Sometimes there‚Äôs nothing to be done ‚Äî in that case, best to do nothing. Good time to visit family üòâ

3/ The folks shouting ‚Äúbitcoin is dead!!!‚Äù are full of shit. But so are the people screaming ‚Äúyay!!! Weak hands are gone!!! Accumulation time!‚Äù They are covering their insecurity with excessive exuberance. It‚Äôs neither a time for terror nor euphoria. Steady hands win over time.
2/ You‚Äôre not alone in your feelings. Corrections this large shake even the most steadfast investors, temporarily. The main difference is in what you choose to do (or not do) about it.

11/ Most importantly, have fun and just keep going. Genuine interest in a topic is the best driver!

10/ Also worth noting that this process works for me because I learn best by reading, & only like learning from others once I have a baseline understanding of the topic. In college, lectures were basically useless for me unless I had read ahead of time. People vary in this regard
9/ Take notes, by hand. I almost never review them but the simple act of writing them forces me to summarize and internalize the concepts.

8/ Reading about the same thing from different sources is great, & should not be viewed as a waste of time. The style / explanation mode of some writers will naturally suit you better,so the same idea which seemed incomprehensible from one source will suddenly click from another.

7/ Spend a couple of days or weeks really going into something and you will both understand and retain it 10x better. This moves it from something that you "learned" (and could forget) to something that you "know" ‚Äì‚Äì in the same way you know your childhood memories (permanent).

6/ I find that concentrated reading about one topic is way more effective for deep understanding and long-term memory gelling than flitting between topics (even if total amount of time is equal in both cases) .

5/ Important: don't worry that you don't understand everything. Just keep reading. Brains are magical in that they will later fish out information that you didn't even know you had archived, and all of a sudden the full picture starts to form.

4/ Look for articles of increasing complexity. If you need to understand a different concept to move fwd (i.e. need to learn what a Pedersen Commitment is in order to grasp the mechanics of a protocol) open a new tab and do a bit of reading, but don't get stuck.

3/ At the beginning, look for basic articles ‚Äì‚Äì Wikipedia or high-level press. You want to create a very rough sketch in your mind about the topic at hand. There will be lots of holes and fuzzy areas, but you can fill those in later.

2/ I have often been asked how I went about learning about it, as the mechanics of it are pretty complex, esp for someone without a background in CS or cryptography. So in case it's useful for anyone out there, here's what my process for learning about most things looks like:

1/ I spent most of the afternoon reading on Github, and for whatever reason was reminded of the many hours I spent digging through developer docs in 2013 when I first went down the bitcoin rabbit hole (and there was barely anything to read but the developer docs)

6. The best founders are obsessed with bringing whatever it is they‚Äôre building into the world, so having more capital could allow them to execute against that vision faster, without meaningful drop off in motivation as many suggest comes as a result of too much $.
5. The prior assumption requires the belief that founders are, at least to some extent, irresponsible. While this is certainly the case in some instances, I wouldn‚Äôt say it‚Äôs widespread.

4. What if a bigger war chest allows for the pursuit of more ambitious goals? Some of the most meaningful advances society has made required significant capital expenditure. Even assuming a 99% failure rate, could just a few of those be meaningful?

3. The general thinking is that the founders will be less responsible with the cash and spend it more recklessly than they would with a smaller war chest. This may or may not be true, but also begs the question whether more free spending is necessarily a bad thing.

3. Some of my favorite investments required wading through NO excess deals, because they were founders I had known for years, and had high conviction in them as people. IMHO # of deals looked at is really an imperfect metric at best. Curious if anyone has data on this?

6/ Perhaps instead of blaming crypto, let's consider where we are to blame: if it sounds too good to be true, it probably is. Don't buy things you don't understand. And if you are in the position to be selling, remember that there is a real person on the other side of that trade.

5/ Now, people point to this and say "crypto is bad" and "crypto is speculative". This is silly - crypto is only speculative as far as speculate on it. They also do this in any other asset class, and at various points in time speculation on public equities has gotten just as bad.
4/ For goodness sake, do not take out loans to buy crypto (or stocks, or anything else for that matter). You might be right, but if your timing is off, you'll get screwed anyway.

3/ Something that stuck out was that in many cases, the worst of it happened because of leverage. Maybe it's only because "When Genius Failed" is one of the most influential books I ever read, but I think leverage is the devil.

2/ Yes, people should know better than to plow their net worth into something they don't understand. But I also empathize with folks wanting to have their "big break" and seeing crypto as a path to a better financial future.

9/ Investors have many different reasons for why they might choose to invest in a company. Especially if you don‚Äôt know them personally and haven‚Äôt discussed their rationale, it‚Äôs very dangerous to play follow-the-leader. Do your own homework!
8/ You really can‚Äôt draw too many conclusions about why someone made an investment unless you have a comprehensive understanding of their portfolio.

7/ But from an outside perspective, someone seeing a headline ‚ÄúXYZ investor invests in layer-two protocol‚Äù who doesn‚Äôt know this investor is a bitcoin whale might follow XYZ into that investment, without holding any bitcoin, and end up with a very different outcome.

6/ And sometimes, they‚Äôre portfolio-driven:if you are a BTC whale and you think a layer-two scalability solution could make the value of your BTC increase tenfold, it makes sense to invest in the company building the solution whether or not you expect any return from the company.

5/ Sometimes they‚Äôre learning-driven: they may think the company will fail, but want to use the investment to learn more about a particular industry (and compared to college these days, that $50K seems like cheap tuition).

4/ Sometimes they‚Äôre curiosity-driven: the investor might think the company has an extremely low likelihood of succeeding, but find the entrepreneur interesting enough to want to be able to call them up occasionally, which is easier when you‚Äôre an investor in the company.

3/ Sometimes they‚Äôre relationship-driven: if your personal net worth is a few billion, it may literally be easier for you to write a $50K check into a company than it is to deal with saying no. A token investment gets you out of the awkwardness of declining.
2/ Different investors, particularly those writing personal checks, have a whole slew of reasons for which they might invest, many of which are not strictly tied to expected financial upside.

1/ A thread on investor incentives: Lemming behavior in investing is nothing new and not unique to crypto, but it does seem to become more common in complicated, technical realms where investors have a harder time doing their own diligence. Crypto certainly fits that bill.

3/ A majority of those will probably be security tokens, often representing real-world assets. This sounds onerous, but the only reason it is so is that switching costs are high. Once we have better interoperability & cross-chain swap solutions, switching costs get close to 0.

13/ I‚Äôm increasingly convinced that in crypto, the coins with the strongest communities are going to be the winners. As @bendavenport put it, missionaries always trump mercenaries. /fin
12/ Any piece of technology that can create a movement - and a group of people who MUST HAVE IT - is basically unstoppable.
11/ In my mind, this maps to HODLers - they‚Äôre holding for the eventual financial upside, but also due to a strong ideological belief.
10/ The gamers didn‚Äôt have to pay - they chose to, despite it not being immediately financially rational to do so. Amazingly, they donated millions of dollars in this fashion.
9/ The early game creators also pioneered the concept of shareware, where games were distributed for free, and paid for on a voluntary, donation basis by the gamers.
8/ But the most important similarity between today‚Äôs crypto and 1990s gaming worlds is the religious fervor of both communities.

7/ The crypto parallel is scalability: as CryptoKitties demonstrated, right now most dApps are limited by speed and throughout issues on the underlying chains. I believe that like PCs eventually got up to speed, we will figure out how to scale blockchains as well.

6/ Game developers were also limited not by the limits of their creativity, but by the boundaries of the technology. PCs were initially too slow to run any good games - and only eventually did some of the best technical minds come up with solutions.
5/ This is so clearly the phase we are still in for cryptocurrencies and dApps. Most require a decent base of technical knowledge, a willingness to experiment, and a tolerance for poor UX.

4/ It was a huge hassle to play games in the early days - initially they had to be typed in by hand, they were slow, computers weren‚Äôt readily available, etc etc. And yet, gamers couldn‚Äôt get enough of them.

3/ The parallel here is the narrative of crypto being used for drug dealing and nefarious activity - in the early days bitcoin was the target, and now it has become privacy coins. Trying to ban these things rarely (if ever) works.
2/ In the early days, the violence in video games caused a backlash from conservatives who wanted to ban them. One case went all the way to the Supreme Court, but was ultimately dismissed.

6/ Eventually I fell down the crypto rabbit hole & focused my attention there, but the strategy worked well for the time I used it. Maybe I just got lucky a few times, but the realization that the market is often mercurial in the short term was very useful.Crypto is no different!

5/ Indeed, the prices usually bounced back quite a bit in a relatively short time window, often back to or above their initial prices. If you bought at the low and had a bit of patience, you‚Äôd do well.

4/ I didn‚Äôt know a thing about investing at that time (though this first foray into the field kicked off a compulsive need to read everything investment-related I could get my hand on, including lots on value investing) but this incongruity felt wrong.

3/ I started noticing a pattern of these stocks reacting wildly to both positive & negative news (FDA approval/disapproval of a drug). Prices would fall by double-digit percentages on one piece of news, but it was clear the underlying company hadn‚Äôt lost half its value overnight.

2/ Some of my first investments were in pharma equities when I was in my early twenties. I was working at a startup in NY at the time, and my role had nothing to do with investing, but I used to watch the financial shows on cardio-equipment TVs at the gym.

1/ In light of the recent prices moves in the coins that Coinbase announced they may support, it‚Äôs worth noting this kind of market overreaction to a single piece of news isn‚Äôt unique to crypto. A quick trip down memory lane...

In the meantime, invest in your health and restrict your caloric intake. If possible, also become a billionaire üòâ. Jokes aside, if you‚Äôre looking for an intro to the space I recommend @LauraDeming‚Äôs website: https://t.co/qHr82Ibqdg

As is typical in medicine, they will be very expensive and available to only the top 1% or even .0001% to start. Then, massive economic pressure will start to drive those costs down and eventually these treatments will be available to the population at large.

A lot of work is being done in the field of life extension (though interestingly most of the best discoveries have come from research in other areas, i.e. diabetes) so I expect that in the next 10-20 years we will start to have some more actionable life extension cures.

What we DO know is that caloric restriction works (though there‚Äôs still a lot of uncertainty around exactly why and in what contexts) and that generally being in good health keeps you better equipped to deal with whatever illness or aging processes might attack you.
While you can certainly acquire more money later on, even with unlimited funds there is currently little you can do that will with great certainty extend your lifespan.
For Millenials in the top 5% of income, life will probably extend well into the 100s. This requires some serious thinking on our part.

6. An investment firm and a company have different time horizons and incentive structures, and the two should not be confused.

5. Lastly, it is a serious mistake to conflate the skill sets of an maker and that of an investor. Many brilliant engineers are horrible investors, and many great investors could never build much of anything.

4. Perhaps the recent slew of deaths in VC on-demand companies should serve as a reminder that growth is a death sentence when it's not built on solid foundations. In the case of these ecosystem funds, basically none of them are -- because the core protocols aren't even built!

3. These ICOs should have been capped. There is no world in which a pre-product company needs more than 20M. But now that they have it, there's a perverse incentive to allocate it, attempting to buy growth at any cost.

2. I understand that once you have a bazillion dollars you are inclined to feel the need to do something with it. But let's perhaps consider that these absurd amounts of money should not have been raised in the first place!

1. When investors contributed to a project's ICO, they did not contribute so that the company could start a fund. They contributed so that the company could *build the thing* that they claimed they were going to build. Anything else is a distraction.

6/ If anyone has done something similar or has an improved process for this, I'd love to hear about it!

5/ I am going to run an experiment starting now in which I try to keep Mondays (all day) and Friday (afternoons) for alone time -- " learning days" for reading & listening. Eventually I hope this also comes to include writing.
4/ No matter how much you learn in crypto there is always someone who can go deeper in a particular area, and continued learning is *critical* in an industry as complex and fast-moving as this one.

3/ Today, I spent most of the afternoon listening to https://t.co/qsKQ8h1HOK and a couple other podcasts while doing mindless tasks around my house. It was actually an incredibly good use of time - I learned a ton.

2/ It's so easy to become an automata who mindlessly responds to emails, rather than actually carving out time for meaningful research / learning. Ironically, sometimes it feels hard to carve out time for the most important stuff.
1/ I've been thinking a lot about how I use my time lately, and I want to make a conscious effort to be even more proactive (as opposed to reactive) in the coming months.

6) Dress presentably. (For better or worse this matters more if you‚Äôre a woman - I‚Äôm not saying this SHOULD be true but I believe it is, so don‚Äôt shoot the messenger).
5) Ask investors what concerns they have about you or the business at the end of the meeting. You may learn something from them, and it gives you the chance to address potential blockers.
4) Don‚Äôt cold message people on LinkedIn asking them to advise your company. Figure out a way to get a warm intro - chance they accept goes up exponentially.
3) Offer weekend availability to meet investors. You‚Äôll probably get more time with them than you might otherwise. Many investors (especially younger ones) work through the weekend.
2) Make an effort to be high energy when you‚Äôre pitching. If YOU don‚Äôt seem excited about what you‚Äôre doing, how can you expect the investor to get excited?

7/ If you understand the difference between the two, you can use this to your advantage. It's not hard -- just requires a bit of emotional self-regulation, which is critical in most types of investing.
6/ I think in the long-term, we'll overcome the short term panic selling (as we saw w Mt Gox) and instead the currencies that are proven to be technically weak will die.
5/ On the other hand, in mid 2017 a flaw in Cryptonote was discovered which allowed malicious actors to print coins out of thin air in any currencies built on Cryptonote -- and prices went up!

4/ Similarly, the markets seem to be down today on the @coincheckjp hack news, which is rumored to be north of $600M. Again, from what little information seems to be floating around, this has nothing to do w issues in NEM (which seems to be most of what was stolen).
3/ There is a *massive* difference between the two issues. When Mt Gox was hacked, there was no fundamental problem with bitcoin -- it was a Mt Gox issue.

2/ It's worth noting that the market seems to be unable to distinguish between hacks (not a technical problem with crypto, IMO will eventually become a much smaller problem) and actual technical vulnerabilities.

9/ It's actually somewhat miraculous that bitcoin has gotten to where it has -- and this is meaningful. I wouldn't bet against it just yet.

8/ I will add that the equation does not work the same with the long tail of coins. I look at a lot of new projects and early coins, and most of those purporting to be the "next" btc / eth etc will never become that. Be careful.

7/ You can only ever lose what you've put in, but I believe the likelihood for a 10x+ in BTC (yes, really!) is much greater than for most stocks. Downside is capped; upside is uncapped -- overall an attractive risk / reward profile.

6/ This will sound crazy to most, but I don't think the likelihood that bitcoin goes to zero is much higher than that most public stocks are wiped out. In 2013, that risk was much greater for bitcoin. But as the number of hodlers increases, network effects become stronger.
5/ Stocks have become widely regarded as a "safe" investment -- memories from 2008 and past major financial crises are quickly forgotten. However, they can -- and do! -- go to zero.
4/ I would actually propose that on a risk-adjusted basis, investing in bitcoin and a couple other top market cap coins is a much sounder investment than in most publicly traded stocks.
3/ Of course there is a chance bitcoin fails -- there is also a chance Facebook, Google, and Amazon do, though nobody seems to need to caveat their investments in those companies in this way.

2/ There are a number of factors that seem to support this notion: Bitcoin dominance as a % of total crypto markets is decreasing, there are lots of "shiny new toy" cryptos which have seen higher % returns in the past year etc. BUT

1/ It's become very in vogue to assert that there are good chances that bitcoin "may fail".This is basically a hedge statement that most investors feel compelled to make. It's also meaningless, because you can easily use it, sound thoughtful, & not actually convey a real opinion.

5/ Obviously if you are managing money as a fund you're making different tradeoffs, but that's how I feel about the coins I've had since 2013. This is actually an important thing to note from a macro perspective, because so much of the market is still held by ideologue whales.

4/ I have never had this sort of attachment to a public stock or any other similar type of investment, because I never believed in the mission to the extent to which I believe in crypto, and bitcoin in particular.

3/ In terms of my personal holdings of bitcoin for example, there's almost no price at which I would sell. Not anywhere close to where we are now, anyways. If it came to it, I would pretty much sell all my other assets before those.

2/ I think this is mostly true of folks who were in crypto early, because they came in for ideological reasons, rather than financial ones. This is a far cry from the current state of affairs, where shitcoins are the rage as everyone(fruitlessly, IMO) scavenges for the "next" BTC

1/ One fascinating thing about crypto is how attached you can become to your coins. Irrationally, so, perhaps. I know this is true because it's how I feel, and I'm definitely not the only one. I don't really enumerate their value in fiat, either.
